text: Gracias por venir, in Spanish, means thanks for coming.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So there's two things that we can see in this sentence.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can use these sentences like a hook to remember two important things about Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The first thing is that we have two words for for.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We already saw another word for for.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, how are we saying for me?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we had mí and ti coming with prepositions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Para mí, para ti, de mí, from mí, de ti, from you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But then, for the other people, we just say for he, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how is for him or for he in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this para is when something is for somebody, no?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, if you want to say this is for you, speaking informally, let's say it's a masculine object.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This, this one is for you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that's your hook and you go from there.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But I want a masculine thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What you should do is look at somewhere that you've used it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you should look at this car.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: These are the processes that we're learning and this is half of the method.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can take yourself through those processes when you need to find it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then it comes to your memory.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Then you know it after that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But the first few times you need to have a look around, let's say, and see to find it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this or this one, masculine thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this one is for you, speaking informally.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If we mean a masculine thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What if you meant these are for you?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we saw that actually for this and these we have este and estos.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In este we have the e of el and in estos we have the os of los.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is the for that we learned until now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Then we have por, which is much more flexible.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can use it like because of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes when we say for in English, we mean because of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, if you say for this reason, what you mean is because of this reason.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So por also means for in the sense of because of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And actually in the words because and why, which were...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Here in why we see that it's because of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Why actually means because of what.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that we have the same word for wine because.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: As because means because of that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in both cases you have por meaning because of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So reason in Spanish is razón.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or razón in most of Spain.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But in most of the Spanish speaking world, razón.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say this reason?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say because of this reason, I don't want to go.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because of this reason, I don't want to go.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Por esta razón, no quiero ir.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: Por esta razón, no quiero ir.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can say I'm buying it for you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: That means, you know, this thing I'm buying it for you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But maybe in some context you want to say I'm buying it because of you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it doesn't mean necessarily that this thing is for that person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Just that you've bought it because of that person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So maybe you buy an ashtray in your house and your one friend that smokes comes and you say Lo he comprado por ti.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I have bought it because of you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you say lo he comprado para ti, for you, then he'll want to take the ashtray home.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Another use for por is when we're talking about time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When you're talking about periods of time, for two weeks, for two days, you will not say para, you will say por.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is another place where you use por.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for day is día.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's actually related to an Indo-European root.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It just means a very old root.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Meaning light and deity in English comes from the same root.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or the dj of Jupiter is actually also from this root.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Jupiter means something like the father of the gods.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You have piter like paternal there.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And dj from this same root as día and deity.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And of course you have Jupiter which is the biggest planet.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the father of the gods, Jupiter.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Día is a word that looks feminine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And it's one of those few words that end in a that look feminine that are masculine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the day is el día.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And every day is all the days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Before we said todo el tiempo, to say all the time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to say every day, you say all the days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you think that would sound?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you wanted to say I'm staying for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I remain myself for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I will stay for three days?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I will stay for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't really need, you don't need the will here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The fact that you say for three days is already some kind of future context.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: No, the days didn't happen yet.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I will stay for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In both futures we are adding on to the verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Yes, we are pushing it into the future.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I will stay for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this sounds a little bit more certain, you know, when you use the future.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I will stay for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I would stay for three days?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I would stay for three days.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Wood is I would like or it would please me.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is a nice hook to remember wood.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because it's something that's very common that you will use a lot.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So what is that little bit you need for wood that you can pluck out of me gustaría?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I would stay for three days.

text: You remember what is to work?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I would stay for three days but I have to work.

text: And not from memory but thinking it through again.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I know because I've already forgotten it.

text: Taking that time to think it through again.
